text: You're going to hear five people talking about the impact of tourism on their city.

Honestly, it’s getting a bit too much. I’ve lived in this neighborhood my whole life, and now I can’t even walk down the street without bumping into groups of people taking photos. The noise level is high day and night, and the local shops have become very expensive. I really miss the quiet days before we became so popular.

For me, tourism is a blessing. I own a small souvenir shop near the cathedral, and ninety percent of my customers are visitors. If they stopped coming, I would have to close my business immediately. They bring money into the city and create jobs for young people. We should be grateful for them.

It is a shame to see how our city is changing. We are losing our traditional culture because everything is designed for tourists now. Also, the large tour buses cause a lot of pollution, and the crowds are actually damaging the historic buildings. We need stricter rules to protect our heritage.

The biggest problem is finding a place to live. Landlords prefer to rent their apartments to tourists for short holidays because they can charge more money. As a student, I cannot afford the high rents anymore. I might have to move to a different town just to afford a room.

I actually enjoy the atmosphere. It is exciting to hear so many different languages on the bus or in the park. I have met wonderful people from all over the world right here in my hometown. It makes the city feel more international and alive, which I think is a great thing.
